title-group.article-title: Applications of fuzzy control to nonlinear time-delay systems using the linear matrix inequality fuzzy Lyapunov method

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, Kaohsiung Taiwan
2Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center (GEODAC), National Cheng Kung University, No 1, Ta-Hsueh Road, Tainan 701, Taiwan
3Department of Construction Science and Technology, De-Lin Institute of Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
4Department of Safety, Health and Environmental Engineering, Ming Chi University of Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
5Department of Tourism, Aletheia University, Tamsui, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Cheng-Wu Chen, Institute of Maritime Information and Technology, National Kaohsiung Marine University, Kaohsiung 80543, Taiwan Email: chengwu@mail.nkmu.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study proposes a kind of fuzzy robustness controller design for nonlinear time-delay systems based on the fuzzy Lyapunov method, which is defined in terms of fuzzy blending quadratic Lyapunov functions. The basic idea is to construct the Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model and fuzzy controller for nonlinear dynamic systems with disturbances in which the stability criterion is derived in terms of the fuzzy Lyapunov method. Based on the robustness design and parallel distributed compensation scheme, the problems of modeling errors between real dynamic systems and T-S models are solved. Furthermore, the presented condition is transformed into linear matrix inequalities making it numerically feasible to find the fuzzy state feedback gain and common solutions with the Matlab toolbox. The proposed method is illustrated for a nonlinear chaotic time-delay system and the simulation results show that the robustness controller cannot only stabilize the nonlinear chaotic system, but also has robustness against external disturbances. The simulation is provided to explore the feasibility of the proposed fuzzy controller design method.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Zadeh (1965) initially proposed utilizing a linguistic approach to fuzzy modeling that simulated the thought process and judgment of human beings. Various fuzzy models such as the Mamdani models, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) models, and neuro-fuzzy models have since been developed to improve accuracy and dimensionality, and to simplify the structure of nonlinear systems. The advantage of fuzzy models over conventional mathematical models is they make it possible to elaborate the system using much less information about it. The T-S model, which is first described by Takagi and Sugeno in 1985, also called the Takagi-Sugeno-Kang model, is a quasi-linear or fuzzy linear model. Such models can effectively represent complex nonlinear systems using fuzzy sets. Fuzzy reasoning can then be applied to a set of linear input-output submodels (Cao and Frank, 2001). These fuzzy models represent the local dynamics in different state space regions by linear models. The overall model of the system is achieved by the fuzzy “blending” of these fuzzy models. The employing of linear models in the consequent parts makes it simple to utilize traditional system theory for analysis. Various controllers based on T-S fuzzy models have since been presented (for examples, see Cao et al., 1997; Chen et al., 2004; Ketata et al., 2011; Poursamad and Davaie-Markazi, 2009; Tanaka and Kosaki, 1997; Tanaka and Sano, 1994; and the references therein).

Linear matrix inequality (LMI) theory is a new and rapidly growing field that provides a valuable alternative to the analytical method (see Boyd et al., 1994; Nesterov and Nemirovsky, 1994). LMI conditions are derived via Lyapunov theory to check the stability of T-S fuzzy systems and nonlinear systems. Given an LMI F(x)>0, the LMI problem is to find xfeas such that F(xfeas)>0, or determine that the LMI is infeasible. Many problems arising in system and control theory can be reduced to a few standard convex or quasiconvex optimization problems involving the LMI. The resultant optimization problems can be easily solved with numerical computation, so LMI techniques are highly efficient and practical tools for solving complex control problems (Park et al., 2002). Stability is a critical property of control systems and has been widely investigated in the literature on fuzzy dynamic systems (see Cao et al., 1996; Chen, 2006; Chen et al., 1993; Cuesta et al., 1999; Feng et al., 1997; Margaliot and Langholz, 1999 and 2001; Takagi and Sugeno, 1992; Wang et al., 1996 and the references therein).
The problem of the stabilization of time-delay systems has been explored for several years.

Furthermore, engineering processes commonly involve time delays, which frequently arise in chemical processes and long transmission lines in pneumatic, hydraulic and rolling mill systems. The problem of stability analysis of time-delay systems has been one of the main concerns of research into the properties of such systems. Many monographs on this subject have been published (such as Cao and Frank, 2000, 2001; Hsiao et al., 2005; Li et al., 2004; Liu et al., 2005; Mori, 1985; Tian and Peng, 2006; Trinh and Aldeen, 1995; Yi and Heng, 2002; Zhang and Pheng, 2002). Cao and Frank (2000, 2001) first considered the use of T-S based fuzzy control for nonlinear time-delay systems. Their results of stability analysis did not contain uncertainty. Zhang and Pheng (2002) developed an LMI based approach for the stability analysis of fuzzy control systems with bounded uncertain delays. However, the results of the stability conditions are independent of the size of the time delay.

The criteria for time-delay systems can be divided two parts. One is the delay-independent criterion (see Cao and Frank, 2000, 2001; Yi and Heng, 2002 and the references therein) and the other is the delay-dependent criterion (see Chen and Liu, 2005; Hsiao et al., 2005; Li et al., 2004; Liu et al., 2005; Tian and Peng, 2006), depending on whether the size of the delays is included in the criteria. Generally speaking, delay-dependent results for time-delay systems are less conservative than those for the delay-independent case, especially for time-delay systems with actual small delays (Tian and Peng, 2006). Therefore, considerable attention has been paid to the study of the delay-dependent stability and stabilization for time-delay systems. However, many presented delay-independent results have assumptions in the criteria, which are not feasible, particularly in real applications. Li et al. (2004) applied LMIs to derive a delay-dependent robust stability criterion for T-S fuzzy systems via Lyapunov-Krasovskii functions. They assumed the upper bound of time-derivative of the time delay to be less than one. Hsiao et al. (2005b) presented a delay-dependent stability criterion to guarantee the asymptotic stability of nonlinear multiple time-delay large-scale systems. However, at least two inequalities have to be examined to guarantee the stability of time-delay systems. Therefore, the derivation of generalized and simplified delay-independent stability criteria for nonlinear time-delay systems has not been fully investigated and still remains a challenge.

All the above results consider the stability conditions with the single Lyapunov function, where the stability problem is formulated as a numerically solvable problem based on a common Lyapunov function. Nesterov and Nemirovsky (1994) provided an efficient interior-point algorithm for the solution of stability problems by the convex optimization technique. A simplified LMI condition is derived in this paper. In order to overcome the influence of modeling error between nonlinear systems and fuzzy models, the robustness design is considered.

In recent years, attention has been given to using multiple Lyapunov functions to avoid the conservatism of stability and stabilization problems (for examples, see Chen et al., 2006; El-Farra et al., 2005; Tanaka et al., 2001, 2003). A fuzzy blending of multiple quadratic Lyapunov functions is proposed to find more relaxed stability conditions in these studies. To the best of the authors' knowledge, there are few existing studies on finding delay-independent criteria with fuzzy Lyapunov methods. The fuzzy Lyapunov formulation of fuzzy systems needs further study. This work extends the fuzzy Lyapunov approach for the stability analysis of nonlinear time-delay systems by applying the LMI theory and T-S fuzzy representation to derive a relaxed stability condition. A novel robustness delay-independent LMI-based stability criterion is proposed to overcome the modeling errors between nonlinear time-delay systems and fuzzy models. Based on these criteria, a parallel distributed compensation (PDC) control design with H∞ disturbance attenuation performance is presented to stabilize the nonlinear time-delay systems.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical preliminary procedure
sec.p: Throughout this paper, x(t) represent a continuous-time signal at t. The notations Rg and Rg×m denote real vector space of dimension g and real matrix space of dimension g × m. The symbols AT and In denote the transposition of matrix A and a unit matrix of dimension n.
The notation Mip denotes a fuzzy term of Mp selected for rule i. The symbol Πp=1 gMip=Mi1Mi2…Mig represents a scalar multiplication. The symbol ‖g‖ represents an euclidean norm of vector g.

Definition 1 (Khalil, 1996): The solutions of a dynamic system are said to be uniformly ultimately bounded (UUB) if there exist positive constants ν and κ, and for every δ∈(0,κ) there is a positive constant T=T(δ), such that ‖x(t0)‖<δ⇒‖x(t)‖≤ν,∀t≥t0+T.

Definition 2: V(x(t))=∑i=1 rhi(t)xT(t)Pix(t) is said to be a fuzzy Lyapunov function for the T-S fuzzy system if there exists a positive definite matrix Pi and the time derivative of V(x(t)) is always negative at x(t)≠0.

Definition 3: In order to attenuate the influence of the disturbance ϕ(t) on the state variable x(t), the following H∞ control performance with initial condition is considered: ∫0 tfx(t)TQx(t)dt≤x(0)TPx(0)+η2∫0 tfφ(t)Tφ(t)dt, where P are some positive definite matrices, tf is the terminal time of control, η is a prescribed value which denotes the effect of ϕ(t) on x(t), and Q is a positive definite weighting matrix.

sec.title: 3. Problem formulation
sec.p: Consider a general nonlinear time-delay plant with disturbances to be controlled, described by a dynamical system of the form (1) where the multivariable controller and the disturbance input are defined by (2)

The Expressions (1–2) of the state vector indicate a completely general system and are nonlinear in this paper, which can be written in abbreviated form as (3)x·(t)=f(x(t),x(t-τ),u(t))+φ(t), where x·(t)=[x·1(t),x·2(t),…,x·g(t)]T, x(t)=[x1(t),x2(t),…,xg(t)]T, x(t-τ)=[x1(t-τ),x2(t-τ),…,xg(t-τ)]T, u(t)=[u1(t),u2(t),…,um(t)]T, φ(t)=[φ1(t),φ2(t),…,φq(t)]T, in which x(t)∈Rg denotes the available system state, τ (time delay) is a positive constant, u(t)∈Rm represents the control input vector, and the unknown external disturbance φ(t)∈Rq is upper bounded with a known φup(t). Throughout this paper, the existence of an equilibrium x0∈Rg, i.e., f (x0 = 0) is assumed.

Equation (3) contains global nonlinear functions, but a global control law is not easy to derive based on this kind of model. Takagi and Sugeno (1985) thus proposed a fuzzy dynamic model to represent local linear input–output relations of nonlinear systems. From this, it becomes possible to express a nonlinear system as a linear system in a global region. A number of fuzzy linear systems described by fuzzy IF–THEN rules are used to express the nonlinear system.
Therefore, an equivalent linear input/output nonlinear dynamic fuzzy model to the process can be represented by the following group of rules:

Rule i: (4) where x(t) denotes the output from the ith IF-THEN rule, r is the number of IF-THEN rules, Mip (p=1,2,…,g) is the fuzzy set, z1(t)~zg(t) are the premise variables, (Ai,A¯i,Bi) represents the ith local model of the nonlinear system (4), and Ai∈Rg×g, A¯i∈Rg×g, Bi∈Rg×m. Assume that (Ai,Bi) for i=1,2,…,r are known and controllable. Given a pair of (x(t), u(t)), the resulting output is expressed by the weighted average of the local model. That is, using a singleton fuzzifier, product inference and centre-average defuzzifier, dynamic fuzzy model (4) can be inferred as (5)x·(t)=∑i=1 rhi(t){Aix(t)+A¯ix(t-τ)+Biu(t)}+φ(t), for t ≥0, where hi(t)=wi(t)/∑i=1 rwi(t) in which wi(t)=Πp=1 gMip(zp(t)). In addition, hi(t)≥0 ∀i and ∑i=1 rhi(t)=1.
Based on the approximation of the T-S model, the nonlinear time-delay system (3) can be expressed as (6) where (7) is denoted as the approximation error.

Suppose that there exists a bounding matrix ΔHil such that (8)‖e(t)‖≤‖∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t)ΔHilx(t)‖ for the trajectory x(t), and ΔHil can be described as follows (Chen et al., 1999): (9)ΔHil=δilH¯, where ‖δil‖≤1, for i,l=1,2,…,r. Moreover, the approximation error in equation (7) is bounded by the specified structured bounding matrix H¯. From equations (8) and (9), we have (10)
Equation (10) represents the modeling error bounded by bounding matrix H¯.

sec.title: 4. Fuzzy model-based robustness and H∞ control design
sec.p: The modeling error, e(t), may influence the performance of the system. To stabilize the nonlinear time-delay system (3) subjected to external disturbances and to overcome the effect of modeling error on the state variable x(t), fuzzy model-based robustness and an H infinity control design are thereby proposed to derive stability conditions of the fuzzy system (6).

According to the conventional PDC concept in which the design strategy is to synthesize a local feedback controller for each local subsystem, the fuzzy control law corresponding to T-S fuzzy model (4) is formulated as follows:
Controller Rule i: (11) where Ki ∈Rm×g are constant control gains to be determined. The final control u is inferred using the same inference as before: (12)u(t)=-∑i=1 rhi(t)Kix(t).
Substituting equation (12) into equation (6), the corresponding fuzzy closed-loop system with time-delay is yielded (13)
Before a typical stability condition for time-delay T-S fuzzy system (13) is proposed, some useful concepts are given below:

Lemma 1 (Hsiao et al., 2005): For any A, B∈Rn and for any symmetric positive definite matrix G ∈Rn×n or R, we have -2ATB≤ATGA+BTG-1B. Lemma 2 (Wang et al., 1996): The equilibrium point of closed-loop fuzzy system x·(t) =∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t){(Ai-BiKl)x(t)} is asymptotically stable in the large if there exists a common positive definite matrix P such that
Lemma 2 gives a sufficient condition for ensuring asymptotic stability of closed-loop fuzzy system x·(t)=∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t){(Ai-BiKl)x(t)}. Based on the above inequalities, a stability condition can be derived as follows:

Theorem 1: There exists a fuzzy H∞ controller so that the closed-loop time-delay T-S fuzzy system (13) is UUB stabilized in the large with prescribed H∞ norm bound η, if there exist a symmetric and common positive definite matrix P, positive constants σ and the feedback gains Kl satisfying the following inequality: (14) where (15)Δ=(Ai-BiKl)TP+P(Ai-BiKl), with P=PT>0, for i,l=1,2,…,r .

Remark 1: Since condition (14) implies that condition (15) can be negative, i.e., Δ < 0, then V·(t)<0 when ϕ(t) = 0 and τ = 0. This means that the closed-loop T-S fuzzy system X·(t) =∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t){(Ai-BiKl)X(t)} is asymptotically stable if disturbances and modeling errors are not considered. This stability condition of Theorem 1 can be reduced to that of Lemma 2.
Remark 2: Theorem 1 can be recast as the LMI problem by following the procedure below.

New variables Hil=Ai-BiKl, W=P-1, R¯=R-1 and Yil=HilW are introduced and equation (14) is rewritten as follows: (16)[Yil+Yil T+1η2+σ-1+A¯iR¯Ai TWWW-Q-10W0-R¯]<0, where (17)ψil=Yil+Yil T+1η2EiEi T+A¯iR¯Ai Tandi,l=1,2,…,r

To avoid conservatism of stability and stabilization problems for the time-delay T-S fuzzy systems from being subjected to disturbances, the fuzzy Lyapunov function approach is employed to derive more generalized criteria, as described in the next section.

sec.title: 5. Fuzzy Lyapunov function approach
sec.p: The fuzzy Lyapunov function described in Definition 2 shares the same membership functions with the T-S fuzzy model (see Chen et al., 2006). Similarly, in order to handle the time derivative h·ρ(t) of premise membership functions, an upper bound |h·ρ(t)|≤φρ is adopted.
Theorem 2: The fuzzy system (6) is UUB stabilized in the large if there exist common positive definite matrices P1,P2,…,Pr such that inequality |h·ρ(t)|≤φρ is satisfied and (18)

We assume that x(0) is known and that the inequality |h·ρ(t)|=|∂hρ(t)∂x(t)x·(t)|≤φρ is satisfied, where ∂hρ(t)∂x(t)=∑m=1 sνρm(t)ɛρm, for νρm(t)≥0 and ∑m=1 sνρm(t)=1. To verify the conditions (18), some numerically solvable conditions are presented for the selecting problem of ϕρ in Theorem 3.

Theorem 3: The time-delay system (18) is stable in the large if the constraint |h·ρ(t)|=|∂hρ(t)∂x(t)x·(t)|≤φρ holds and there exist common positive definite matrices P1,P2,…,Pr such that (19)∑i=1 rhi(0)xT(0)Pix(0)≤1 (20)
Remark 3: Theorem 3 can be reformulated into the LMI problem. Therefore, equation (21) is transformed to the following LMI: (21)[1XT(0)PPTX(0)H]≥0, where P=[P1…Pr], H=block-diag[P1h1(0)…Prhr(0)].
Remark 4: Theorem 1 implies that the Theorems 2 and 3 are satisfied when the single Lyapunov function is considered.

sec.title: 6. Examples
sec.p: In this section, the proposed methodology is illustrated on a simulated chaotic system in which the duffing equation is considered for a large displacement when the high order term cannot be ignored. The chaotic system used in this example to verify the effectiveness of the control system is taken from Hsaio et al. (2005), but the parameters are somewhat different. The objective is to design a fuzzy controller such that the simulated nonlinear chaotic system is uniformly ultimately bounded.

Chaotic system: (22){x·1(t)=2.5x2(t){x·2(t)=-(12.5x1(t))3-12.5x1(t)+0.001x1(t-0.001)+0.001x1 2(t-0.001)}+0.001x2(t-0.001)-0.01x2(t)+40cos(1.29t)+fu(t) , where u(t) denotes the control force and f denotes the constant coefficient of control forces.

There exist many sets of harmonic solutions in a chaotic system. When a given initial condition produces a chaotic solution, then an arbitrary initial condition will make the state of a nonlinear system chaotic. In chaos, the system output is extremely sensitive to the initial conditions. Figure 1 shows the responses of the system with no control force corresponding to two almost identical initial conditions, namely x1(0)=1.2, x2(0)=-1.5 (blue line) and x1(0)=1.201, x2(0)=-1.501 (red line). Figure 2 shows the phase-plane trajectory of the same simulation result with x1(0)=1.2, x2(0)=-1.5. Figure 1.
Chaotic behavior of a nonlinear system with no control force. Figure 2.
Phase-plane trajectory of the chaotic system.

Nevertheless, the question remains, how do we design a kind of fuzzy robustness design for nonlinear time-delay systems based on the fuzzy Lyapunov method, which is defined in terms of fuzzy blending quadratic Lyapunov functions? The basic idea of the proposed approach is to construct a fuzzy controller for nonlinear dynamic systems with disturbances in which the delay-independent robust stability criterion is derived in terms of the fuzzy Lyapunov method. Based on the robustness design and PDC scheme, the problems of modeling errors between nonlinear dynamic systems and T-S fuzzy models are solved. The detailed process can be divided into the following steps:

Step 1: Establish a T-S fuzzy model for each nonlinear system. To minimize the design effort and complexity, we try to use as few rules as possible. Hence, the system (22) is represented with the following fuzzy models:
T-S fuzzy model of the chaotic system:
Rule 1: IF x1(t) is M11 Rule 2: IF x1(t) is M21

Te membership functions for Rule 1 and Rule 2 are shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Membership of the chaotic system.
Step 2: In order to stabilize the nonlinear system N¯, two model-based fuzzy controllers designed based on the concept of PDC scheme are displayed below.
Fuzzy controllers of System 1 and System 2:
Rule 1: IF x1(t) is M11 Rule 2: IF x1(t) is M21

Steps 3: In accordance with assumption of equation (9), the bounding matrix is chosen with H¯=[0.01-1.95-0.010.3], δil=I for i,l=1,2. Subsequently, for the purpose of fulfilling the stability conditions of the Theorem, we can obtain the positive definite matrices P and Ki with σ=1.0 and γ=2.0 by LMI optimization algorithms of the Matlab toolbox (for more details on finding common solutions in LMI form, see Boyd et al., 1994; Chen et al., 1999):

Furthermore, the assumption of
is satisfied from the illustration in Figure 4 with x1(0)=1.2, x2(0)=-1.5. Simulation results of each system are illustrated in Figure 5 and control forces are shown in Figure 6. From the Figures 5 and 6, we know the dynamic time-delay system is uniformly ultimately bounded and that means the state is to achieve the stability of the Definition 1 by the harmonic control force. Figure 4.
Plots of ‖f¯(x(t))-∑i=1 2∑l=1 2hi(t)hl(t)(Ai-BiKl)x(t)‖ (dashed line) and ‖∑i=1 2∑l=1 2hi(t)hl(t)ΔHilx(t)‖ (solid line). Figure 5.
State response of the chaotic system. Figure 6.
Control force of the chaotic system.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: There has been increasing interest in optimal computing and its applications in recent years, such as intelligent robots, artificial intelligence, and so on (for example, see Chen, 2006; Chen et al., 2006; 2007; 2008; 2009; 2010; Chiang, et al., 2010; Hsiao et al., 2005; Chen and Chen (2010); Hsieh et al. (2006); Limanond and Si (1998); Rhee and Sangchul (2006); Shih, Chen and Chou (2011); Chen (2010); Chen (2011a,b,c,d); Lu et al., (2003); Chiou et al., (2011), Lin and Chen, 2010a,b; Lin et al., 2009; Liu et al., 2011; Tang et al., 2011; Tsai et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008; Yeh and Chen, 2010; Yeh et al., 2008). This investigation addresses the stability problem of time-delay T-S fuzzy systems subjected to disturbances. First, the T-S fuzzy model is used to model the dynamic system and the PDC technique is formulated for the design of a fuzzy model-based controller, then a robustness design of fuzzy control via model-based approach is proposed to overcome the modeling error. A novel delay-independent stability criterion, presented in terms of the fuzzy Lyapunov method, is merged with LMI theory to ensure the asymptotic stability of the time-delay T-S fuzzy systems. According to this criterion, a model-based fuzzy controller is developed to stabilize a nonlinear time-delay system. Furthermore, H infinity control performance is achieved by the PDC controller design. Finally, an example is given to illustrate the concepts discussed in this paper.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are most grateful for the kind assistance of Prof. Ali Nayfeh, Editor of JVC, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which has led to the making of several corrections which have greatly aided us to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.p: Proof of Theorem 1: Using the Lyapunov function candidate for the fuzzy system (10) (A.1)V=xT(t)Px(t)+∫0 τxT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)dτ, where V > 0 and the weighting matrix R=RT>0. The time derivative of V is (A.2)V·=x·T(t)Px(t)+xT(t)Px·(t)+xT(t)Rx(t)-xT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)= {∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t)[(Ai-BiKl)x(t)+A¯ix(t-τ)] +φ(t)+e(t) }TPx(t)+xT(t)P {∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t) [(Ai-BiKl)x(t) +A¯ix(t-τ) ]]+φ(t)+e(t) }+∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t)[xT(t)Rx(t)-xT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)] (A.3)

Based on Lemma1 and equation (A.3), we have (A.4)V·≤∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t)xT(t) ×[(Ai-BiKl)TP+P(Ai-BiKl)+R+1η2PP]x(t) +∑i=1 r∑l=1 rhi(t)hl(t) [xT(t)PA¯iR-1A¯i TPx(t) +xT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)-xT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)] -(1ηPTx(t)-ηφ(t))T(1ηPTx(t)-ηφ(t)) +η2‖φup(t)‖2+σ[eT(t)e(t)]+σ-1[xT(t)PPx(t)],
Based on equation (10) and equation (A.4), we have (A.5)
Based on Theorem 1 and equation (A.5), (A.6)
Integrating (A.6) from t=0 to t=tf and noting equation (A.1), we get (A.7)∫0 tfX(t)TQX(t)dt≤XT(0)PX(0)+η2∫0 tfφ(t)Tφ(t)dt.
Equation (A.7) is Lemma 3. Therefore, the H∞ control performance is achieved.
Proof of Theorem 2: Consider the Lyapunov function candidate for the fuzzy system (6) (A.8)V(x(t))=∑i=1 rhi(t)xT(t)Pix(t)+∫0 τxT(t-τ)Rx(t-τ)dτ.
The time derivative of V is (A.9)
Based on Lemma 1 and (A.9), we get (A.10)
Based on equations (10) and (A.10), we have (A.11)
Based on Theorem 2 and equations (A.8) and (A.11), the following inequality will be satisfied by integration: (A.12)∫0 tfx(t)TQx(t)dt≤xT(0)Px(0)+η2∫0 tfφ(t)Tφ(t)dt.
Equation (A.12) is Lemma 3. Therefore, the H∞ control performance is achieved. That is, V·(x(t))< 0 at x(t)≠0 if equation (A.12) holds.
Proof of Theorem 3: From |h·ρ(t)|=|∂hρ(t)∂x(t)x·(t)|≤φρ, we have (A.13)(∂hρ(t)∂x(t)x·(t))T(∂hρ(t)∂x(t)x·(t))≤φρ 2.
From (A.13) and time-delay system (18), we have (A.14)

Assume that equation (17) is a fuzzy Lyapunov function and ∑i=1 rhi(0)XT(0)PiX(0)≤1. So, (A.15)∑i=1 rhi(t)XT(t)PiX(t)≤∑i=1 rhi(0)XT(0)PiX(0)≤1 and inequality (20) in Remark 4 is satisfied if (A.14) holds. From (A.14), (A.15) and the variable φ¯ρ=φρ -2, we get
where the symbol * denotes the transposed elements in the symmetric positions and the proof is thereby completed.
